terms.definition: A retirement account (401(k), traditional IRA) where contributions are tax-deductible and growth is tax-free until withdrawal.
terms.example: Contributing $6,000 to a traditional IRA in the 22% bracket saves $1,320 in taxes immediately

terms.definition: A retirement account (Roth 401(k), Roth IRA) funded with after-tax dollars where all growth and qualified withdrawals are tax-free forever.
terms.example: $6,000/year in Roth grows to $1.2M by age 65â€”all tax-free withdrawals in retirement

terms.definition: Tax on profit from selling investments. Short-term (<1 year) taxed as ordinary income; long-term (â‰¥1 year) receives preferential lower rates.
terms.example: In {{STATE_NAME}}, capital gains are taxed at {{STATE_CAPITAL_GAINS_TAX}}% state rate plus 0-20% federal

terms.definition: Selling investments at a loss to offset capital gains and reduce taxable income, then reinvesting in similar assets.
terms.example: Realizing a $3,000 loss can offset $3,000 in gains, saving $450+ in taxes at 15% rate

content.headerTitle: The Three Pillars of Tax-Efficient Investing

leftPanel.title: State Taxes Matter for Investors
paragraphs: As a {{STATE_NAME}} ({{STATE_CODE}}) resident, your investment income faces both federal AND state taxes. This significantly impacts your after-tax returns.
Unlike states with 0% income tax (Florida, Texas, Nevada, etc.), {{STATE_NAME}} investors must consider the {{STATE_INCOME_TAX_RATE}}% state tax on investment income.
This makes tax-advantaged accounts even MORE valuable for {{STATE_NAME}} residents compared to residents of zero-tax states.

content.headerTitle: The Compound Impact of Tax Efficiency

layoutData.title: Tax Drag Destroys Wealth Over Time
paragraphs: A 1-2% annual tax drag might seem small, but it compounds dramatically over decades. For {{STATE_NAME}} investors, proper tax strategy is essential.
bulletPoints: 7% return vs 5% after-tax: $10,000 becomes $76,000 vs $43,000 over 30 years
That 2% difference: $33,000 lost to taxes on a single $10,000 investment
For {{STATE_NAME}}: At {{STATE_INCOME_TAX_RATE}}% state tax, tax-advantaged accounts are even more valuable
Lifetime impact: Tax efficiency can add $200,000-$500,000 to your wealth

keyPoint.text: Tax efficiency is the only "free money" in investingâ€”it costs nothing to implement but can dramatically increase your wealth.

scenario.name: Jamal: Young Professional, Age 23
paragraphs: Jamal started his first job earning $48,000, placing him in the 12% federal bracket. He researched tax-efficient strategies and made smart choices:
Strategy: $3,000/year to Roth 401(k) (paying just 12% now) + $3,000/year to taxable account with index funds (tax-efficient). Bonds and REITs went into his Roth.
Result by age 65: $1.2M in Roth (100% tax-free) + $1.2M in taxable with $750K unrealized gains (taxed only when sold at preferential rates).

scenario.name: Maya: Mid-Career Professional in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Maya, 34, earning $90,000 in {{STATE_NAME}}, reviewed her taxable account in December. She had a $6,000 capital gain from selling stocks and noticed two positions with losses:
Action: She sold a tech stock ($2,000 loss) and an international fund ($1,500 loss) to realize $3,500 in losses. Immediately purchased similar (not identical) funds to maintain allocation.
Tax Savings: $3,500 offset reduced her taxable gains to $2,500. At 15% federal + {{STATE_CAPITAL_GAINS_TAX}}% state, she saved $525+ in taxes.

content.question:
If you hold a stock for 11 months with a $5,000 gain
and need the money soon, should you wait one more month
to get long-term capital gains treatment?

What factors would influence your decision?

questions.question: Wrong account for wrong asset: Holding bonds in taxable accounts (paying {{STATE_INCOME_TAX_RATE}}% state + federal on interest) instead of tax-advantaged accounts.
Selling too early: Realizing gains at 11 months (short-term) instead of waiting for long-term ratesâ€”can cost 20%+ extra in taxes.
Ignoring tax-loss harvesting: Letting losses "sit" instead of harvesting to offset gains. Leaving money on the table every year.
All traditional, no Roth: Missing tax diversification. Having some Roth gives flexibility to manage taxes in retirement.

takeaways.title: Account Type Matters
takeaways.description: Traditional, Roth, and taxable accounts have different tax treatmentsâ€”use all three strategically based on your situation

takeaways.title: Asset Location Saves Money
takeaways.description: Put tax-inefficient assets (bonds, REITs) in tax-advantaged accounts; tax-efficient assets (index funds) in taxable

takeaways.title: Hold for Long-Term Rates
takeaways.description: Waiting 1+ year drops capital gains taxes from ordinary rates (up to 37%) to preferential rates (0-20%)
